title: 107_hr2281
content: The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2001" allows for a credit for low-income individuals purchasing computers under section 35 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2001" provides a tax credit for eligible individuals who purchase qualified computer technology or equipment, allowing a credit of 50% of the amount paid, up to a maximum of $500 per year. Eligible individuals are those who qualify for the earned income credit. The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2001" offers a tax credit for eligible individuals purchasing qualified computer technology or equipment, excluding certain software and requiring internet capability. The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2001" includes amendments to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of such Code. SEC. 35. Purchase of computers by low-income individuals. SEC. 36. Overpayments of tax. Effective Date: Amendments apply to taxable years after enactment. SEC. 3. Extension and expansion of enhanced deduction for charitable contributions of computers. Extension of the special rule for contributions of computer technology and equipment under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the deadline to June 30, 2004. Additionally, there is an expansion of the rules for qualified computer contributions. The special rule for contributions of computer technology and equipment under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the deadline to June 30, 2004. The term 'qualified computer contribution' refers to a charitable contribution by a corporation of computer technology or equipment to a qualified organization within 3 years of acquisition. The property construction is substantially completed, the original use is by the donor or donee, use within the US, not transferred for money or services, except for certain costs. The property must fit into the educational organization's plan, be used and disposed of according to specific provisions, and meet minimum functionality and suitability standards for educational purposes. A qualified organization is defined as one that meets certain criteria. An organization, including educational organizations and public libraries in designated areas, must meet specific criteria to qualify for certain provisions. An organization, including educational organizations and public libraries in designated areas, must meet specific criteria to qualify for certain provisions. The term 'qualified educational organization' refers to educational organizations described in subsection (b)(1)(A)(ii). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act for qualified educational organizations supporting elementary and secondary education.
